channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Grilled by Senate, Boeing CEO admits to "serious missteps" on safety
item.description: Boeing's CEO admits the company "made serious missteps" that hurt the safety of its planes. But denies the company pressures workers to speed up airplane production.
item.content:encoded:
Boeing's CEO admits the company "made serious missteps" that hurt the safety of its planes. But denies the company pressures workers to speed up airplane production.

(Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)
item.dc:creator: David Schaper

item.title: Senate rebukes Trump's tariffs on Canada
item.description: A bipartisan group of Senators voted to remove the emergency declaration President Trump used to impose 25 percent tariffs on Canada. The vote was largely symbolic since the House isn't expected to act.
item.content:encoded:
A bipartisan group of Senators voted to remove the emergency declaration President Trump used to impose 25 percent tariffs on Canada. The vote was largely symbolic since the House isn't expected to act.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite/AP)
item.dc:creator: Deirdre Walsh

item.title: White House reviewing TikTok proposal to lease algorithm from China
item.description: President Trump and top officials are considering a deal that would create a new U.S. entity and lease TikTok's algorithm to get around China export regulations.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump and top officials are considering a deal that would create a new U.S. entity and lease TikTok's algorithm to get around China export regulations.

(Image credit: Mario Tama)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: Parents sue Bucknell alleging hazing led to freshman football player's death
item.description: Freshman Calvin "CJ" Dickey Jr., died after his first practice at the university. His parents are suing the school, also alleging staff neglected to account for his sickle cell trait during training.
item.content:encoded: Freshman Calvin "CJ" Dickey Jr., died after his first practice at the university. His parents are suing the school, also alleging staff neglected to account for his sickle cell trait during training.
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: Central U.S. braces for tornadoes and flash flooding as powerful storm approaches
item.description: The National Weather Service says a "multi-day catastrophic and potentially historic" storm is expected to impact multiple states beginning on Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: The National Weather Service says a "multi-day catastrophic and potentially historic" storm is expected to impact multiple states beginning on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: Supreme Court hears case that could see more Planned Parenthood clinics closed
item.description: The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether South Carolina can remove Planned Parenthood clinics from its state Medicaid program, even though those funds cannot generally be used to fund abortions.
item.content:encoded:
The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether South Carolina can remove Planned Parenthood clinics from its state Medicaid program, even though those funds cannot generally be used to fund abortions.

(Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: Sen. Cory Booker on his marathon, 25-hour speech on the Senate floor
item.description: Sen. Cory Booker, a Democrat from New Jersey, told NPR's Juana Summers he stopped eating and drinking before his record-breaking speech.
item.content:encoded:
Sen. Cory Booker, a Democrat from New Jersey, told NPR's Juana Summers he stopped eating and drinking before his record-breaking speech.

(Image credit: Roberto Schmidt)
item.dc:creator: Juana Summers

item.title: Senate Republicans move forward with their budget plan to promote Trump's agenda
item.description: If passed, the package could become a hallmark of President Trump's second term. But a number of obstacles remain ahead.
item.content:encoded:
If passed, the package could become a hallmark of President Trump's second term. But a number of obstacles remain ahead.

(Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: Who loses when Trump cuts funding to universities?
item.description:
Eight-point-seven billion.

Four-hundred million.

One-hundred-seventy-five million.

These are just some examples of the money the federal government has withheld or is threatening to withhold from various colleges and universities, including the University of Pennsylvania, Columbia University and Harvard University.

That $8.7 billion figure was announced earlier this week by the Trump administration, which said that it's reviewing federal grants and contracts awarded to Harvard because Harvard has not done enough to curb antisemitism on campus.

Some educators say the administration's moves to cut funding at colleges and universities amounts to a war on higher education. But the loss of those funds will be felt far beyond the college campuses.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
Eight-point-seven billion.

Four-hundred million.

One-hundred-seventy-five million.

These are just some examples of the money the federal government has withheld or is threatening to withhold from various colleges and universities, including the University of Pennsylvania, Columbia University and Harvard University.

That $8.7 billion figure was announced earlier this week by the Trump administration, which said that it's reviewing federal grants and contracts awarded to Harvard because Harvard has not done enough to curb antisemitism on campus.

Some educators say the administration's moves to cut funding at colleges and universities amounts to a war on higher education. But the loss of those funds will be felt far beyond the college campuses.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Scott Eisen)

item.title: Syria Struggles to Find Unity
item.description: The new government in Syria, formed after the fall of dictator Bashar al-Assad, is working to disband local militias to form one national army. But some groups are refusing to join. We meet one very well armed religious minority called the Druse. They say they're afraid of sectarian attacks from the new government and will not be giving up their weapons.
item.content:encoded: The new government in Syria, formed after the fall of dictator Bashar al-Assad, is working to disband local militias to form one national army. But some groups are refusing to join. We meet one very well armed religious minority called the Druse. They say they're afraid of sectarian attacks from the new government and will not be giving up their weapons.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
